scenarios.name: Process Injection
scenarios.description: Tests the ability to inject code into legitimate processes to evade process-based defenses and elevate access. This technique is commonly used by malware to hide malicious activity within trusted processes.
scenarios.fullDescription: Process injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process. Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges.

scenarios.name: Obfuscated Files or Information
scenarios.description: Tests detection of obfuscated malicious content designed to hide the true intent and evade static analysis. Includes various encoding, encryption, and packing techniques.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may attempt to make an executable or file difficult to discover or analyze by encrypting, encoding, or otherwise obfuscating its contents on the system or in transit.

scenarios.name: System Binary Proxy Execution
scenarios.description: Tests the use of legitimate system binaries to proxy execution of malicious code. This technique leverages trusted applications to bypass application controls.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may bypass process and/or signature-based defenses by proxying execution of malicious content with signed binaries.

scenarios.name: OS Credential Dumping
scenarios.description: Tests the ability to detect credential dumping attempts from various OS sources including LSASS, SAM database, and memory structures commonly targeted by attackers.
scenarios.fullDescription: Adversaries may attempt to dump credentials to obtain account login and credential material, normally in the form of a hash or a clear text password, from the operating system and software.
